Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Genome-wide Approaches to Elucidating the Role of Nonsense-mediated mRNA Decay in Regulating Gene Expression

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Cells have evolved elaborate mechanisms to ensure faithful expression of the genetic material. In cases where DNA copies harbor mutations that lead to expression of incomplete proteins, a quality control strategy distinguishes and rapidly eliminates the aberrant material from the cell. How the cell provides this critical safeguard while maintaining accurate gene expression remains an important unanswered biological question. Using a comprehensive set of emerging scientific technologies, this research will identify and characterize the targets of this quality control pathway in an effort to better understand how this level of protective gene regulation is achieved.

Broader Impacts: The research objectives outlined in this project provide an ideal framework to educate, train, and mentor high school, undergraduate and graduate students in critical thinking, scientific method, and hands-on experimental approaches. The development of research skills by junior scientists in the laboratory will be coupled with the launch of an undergraduate course directed at preparing women and minorities pursuing careers in science, engineering and mathematics for academic and institutional challenges they might face and resources available to help maximize success in these fields. Together, these classroom and laboratory opportunities will strengthen the learning and enhance the competitiveness of young scientists at various stages of their training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to apply cutting-edge, genome-wide approaches to identify and assemble a comprehensive list of RNAs targeted by a specialized cellular quality control process that serves to maintain fidelity during gene expression. This dataset was then to be used as a framework to further our understanding of the mechanism by which cells correctly identify faulty RNAs and how such recognition is coupled to their rapid elimination from the cell.

 

Intellectual Merit

Our approach successfully led to a high-confidence dataset of RNAs targeted by this cellular surveillance processes that we continue to mine as a means to identify key features within the RNA necessary for their recognition. Strikingly, this dataset revealed that a subset of biologically-important RNAs previously predicted to be non-coding and to evade quality control  (i.e. long non-coding RNA) is indeed subject to this process and, in many cases, produce small proteins that play important biological roles in the cell. Further, our work has characterized a number of novel mutants of the surveillance machinery and provided novel insight into the mechanism underlying this critical cellular process.

 

Broadly, our findings from this project expanded our overall appreciation and understanding of gene expression and the role quality control plays in the process. We successfully achieved many of our aims and in doing so also uncovered an entire class of protein-coding RNA that was previously disregarded. This research - deemed basic or fundamental in nature - has provided critical advances and will have far-reaching implications in our understanding of how living things coordinate and maintain their activities. 

 

Broader Impacts

Funding from this project supported the scientific training of dozens of students at all levels and backgrounds (namely female, under-represented minorities, 1st-time college enrollees, and those from under-served populations), including: five (5) graduate students; two (2) undergraduate science majors from CWRU and five (5) from Cuyahoga Community College, a dozen (12) students from three local high schools, and four (4) research staff, including a computational biologist. Dedicated mentorship and training were provided to all project members to enhance not only scientific and experimental skills, but also critical thinking, verbal and written communication, professional development and networking, and resulted in the majority of trainees going on to pursue further education or employment opportunities in STEM fields. This work provided an important platform for enhancing inclusion and diversity in science and establishing ourselves as leaders in applying global approaches to analyzing gene expression - for which we openly provide knowledge, resources, and products to colleagues regionally, nationally, and world-wide.
